qas.question: What verb form is found in Czech dictionaries?
How many grammatical moods do Czech verbs have?
What are the grammatical moods of Czech verbs?
What mood adds specific endings for each of three person or number categories?
Which Czech verb mood indicates possible events?
What three grammatical moods are there in English?
What verb form is found in English dictionaries?
How many grammatical moods do English verbs have?
What kind of endings does the conditional mood add for each category in English?
The imperative mood is formed with a particle after what in English?

context: The <a0_0><b6_0>infinitive<b6_0/><a0_0/> form ends in t (archaically, ti). It is the form found in dictionaries and the form that follows auxiliary verbs (for example, můžu tě slyšet—"I can hear you"). Czech verbs have <a1_0><b7_0>three<b7_0/><a1_0/> grammatical moods: <a2_0><b5_0>indicative, imperative and conditional<b5_0/><a2_0/>. The <a3_0>imperative<a3_0/> mood adds <b8_0>specific endings<b8_0/> for each of three person (or number) categories: -Ø/-i/-ej for second-person singular, -te/-ete/-ejte for second-person plural and -me/-eme/-ejme for first-person plural. The <a4_0>conditional<a4_0/> mood is formed with a particle after <b9_0>the past-tense verb<b9_0/>. This mood indicates possible events, expressed in English as "I would" or "I wish".
